qas.question: What is another name for electric-field?
How many polarizations will a antenna have when mounted vertically?
Whats understood in reference of direction of an E-plane?
When is a magnetic fields right angles to a electrical field?

context: The polarization of an antenna refers to the orientation of the electric field (<a0_0>E-plane<a0_0/>) of the radio wave with respect to the Earth's surface and is determined by the physical structure of the antenna and by its orientation; note that this designation is totally distinct from the antenna's directionality. Thus, a simple straight wire antenna will have <a1_0>one<a1_0/> polarization when mounted vertically, and a different polarization when mounted horizontally. As a <a3_0>transverse wave<a3_0/>, the magnetic field of a radio wave is at right angles to that of the electric field, but by convention, talk of an antenna's "<a2_0>polarization<a2_0/>" is understood to refer to the direction of the electric field.
